NIPALS¶

Nonlinear Iterative Partial Least Squares [REFERENCE HERE].

class PLSLib.nipals.nipals¶

Orthogonal weights: \(W^T_q W_q = I_q\)

Envelope connection: \(\mathrm{span}(W_q)=\mathcal{E}_{\Sigma_X}(\mathcal{B})\), the \(\Sigma_X\)-envelope of \(\mathcal{B}\mathrel{\vcenter{:}}=\mathrm{span}(\beta)\).

Score matrix \(S_d\): These are traditional computational intermediaries, although they are not needed in the computation of \(\hat{\beta}_{\mathrm{npls}}\).

Algorithm \(\mathbb{N}\): This is an instance of Algorithm \(\mathbb{N}\) discussed in §1.5.3.

PLS1 v. PLS2: Algorithm is applicable for PLS1 or PLS2 fits; See §3.8.

PLSLib.nipals.nipals.fit(self, X, Y, q, version='sample')¶

Fit this model to the training data X, Y using q dimensions.

Parameters:

  • X (array-like) – Predictor of shape (n_samples, p_features)

  • Y (array-like) – Response of shape (n_samples, r_features)

  • q (int) – Value between 1 and p_features. The number of projections used.

  • version (str) – either ‘sample’ or ‘population’, defaults to ‘sample’

Returns:

Nothing.

PLSLib.nipals.nipals.transform(self, X)¶

Transform data using the NIPALS algorithm. Must run NIPALS.nipals.nipals.fit() before running this function.

Parameters:

X (array-like) – Predictor of shape (n_samples, p_features)

Returns:

The \(W\) and \(\beta\) transformed data, respectively.

Return type:

tuple(array-like, array-like)

PLSLib.nipals.nipals.get_transformers(self)¶

Gets the matrices used to transform the data. Must run NIPALS.nipals.nipals.fit() before running this function.

Returns:

The \(W\) and \(\beta\) transformed data, respectively.

Return type:

tuple(array-like, array-like)
